revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}}
This '''timeline of extinctions''' is an historical account of species that have become [[extinction|extinct]] during the time that modern humans have occupied the earth.
The following is a selective list made by sampling a very small proportion, mostly [[mammal]]s, of some of the well-known extinct species in the recent history. For a more elaborate list see [[Lists of extinct animals]]. The vast majority of extinctions, though, are thought to be undocumented. According to the [[species-area curve|species-area theory]] and based on upper-bound estimating, the present rate of extinction may be up to 140,000 species per year.<ref name=":1">S.L. Pimm, G.J. Russell, J.L. Gittleman and T.M. Brooks, ''The Future of Biodiversity'', [[Science (journal)|Science]] 269: 347–350 (1995)</ref> See [[Holocene extinction]] for more information. {{TOC right}}
==10th millennium ''[[Common Era|BCE]]''== * ''c.'' 9950 BCE - ''[[Cuvieronius|Cuvieronius humboldti]]'' survived in [[Chile]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes">{{cite book|title=American megafaunal extinctions at the end of the Pleistocene|last=Haynes|first=Gary|year=2009|publisher=Springer|isbn=1-4020-8792-6|pages=23, 27–31, 133, 152–53, 172|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iq6qZXUkWo0C&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=28 February 2012}}</ref> * ''c.'' 9940 BCE - ''[[Dow's puffin|Fratercula dowi]]'' survived in the [[Channel Islands (California)|Channel Islands]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey">{{cite book|title=Holocene extinctions|last=Turvey|first=Sam|year=2009|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0-19-953509-4|pages=20–33, 42–50, 64–94, 352|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mbU-F42JU1AC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=29 February 2012}}</ref> * ''c.'' 9680 BCE - ''[[Euceratherium|Euceratherium collinum]]'' survived in [[Utah]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9650 BCE - ''[[Arctotherium|Arctotherium tarijense]]'' survived in [[Uruguay]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9530 BCE - The [[Arctodus|short-faced bear]] ''Arctodus simus'' survived in [[Ohio]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9400 BCE - The [[Corsica]]n and [[Sardinia]]n [[Canidae|canid]] ''[[Sardinian dhole|Cynotherium sardous]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 9390 BCE - ''[[Eremotherium|Eremotherium laurillardi]]'' survived in [[Brazil]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9380 BCE - ''[[Stockoceros]]'' survived in [[New Mexico]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} ''[[Equus conversidens]]'' survived in [[Alberta]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9220 BCE - The pronghorn ''[[Capromeryx]]'' survived in New Mexico until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} ''[[Equus scotti]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Kurten">{{cite book|title=Pleistocene mammals of North America|last=Kurtén|first=Björn|author2=Anderson, Elaine|year=1980|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|isbn=0-231-03733-3|pages=364–65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f8pviaxPIKEC&source=gbs_book_similarbooks|accessdate=29 February 2012}}</ref> * ''c.'' 9180 BCE - ''[[Bison antiquus]]'' survived in Alberta until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9150 BCE - The woodland musk ox ''[[Caprinae#Fossil genera|Symbos]]'' survived in [[Michigan]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=81}} * ''c.'' 9135 BCE - ''[[Panthera onca mesembrina]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9110 BCE - The [[Platygonus|flat-headed peccary]] ''Platygonus compressus'' survived in Ohio until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9090 BCE - ''[[Scelidotherium]]''{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=55}} and ''[[Stegomastodon]]'' survived in [[Brazil]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=85}} * ''c.'' 9080 BCE - The [[pygmy mammoth]] survived on [[Santa Rosa Island, California|Santa Rosa Island]], California until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 9030 BCE - ''[[Bootherium bombifrons]]'' survived in [[Alberta]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/>
==9th millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 8920 BCE - ''[[Harrington's mountain goat|Oreamnos harringtoni]]'' survived in [[Arizona]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 8735 BCE - ''[[Hippidion|Hippidion saldiasi]]'' survived in Chile until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/> * ''c.'' 8445 BCE - The mastodont ''[[Mastodon|Mammut]]'' survived in Michigan until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} * ''c.'' 8420 BCE - ''[[Martes|Martes nobilis]]'' and ''[[American lion|Panthera leo atrox]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Kurten"/> * ''c.'' 8280 BCE - The giant beaver ''[[Castoroides]]'' and the stag-moose ''[[Stag-moose|Cervalces]]'' survived in Ohio until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} * ''c.'' 8240 BCE - ''[[Equus neogeus]]'', ''[[Glyptodon]]'', and ''[[Toxodon]]'' survived in Argentina until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/>
==8th millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 7930 BCE - The [[Pampatheriidae|pampathere]] ''[[Holmesina]]'' survived in Florida until about this time,{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=51}} as did ''[[Glossotherium]]''.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=54}} ''[[Tapirus|Tapirus veroensis]]'' and ''[[Palaeolama|Palaeolama mirifica]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Kurten"/> * ''c.'' 7890 BCE - Mummified skin associated with the sloth ''[[Nothrotheriops|Nothrotheriops shastensis]]'' indicates that the species may have survived in New Mexico until about this time.{{Sfn|Lucas|Sullivan|2015|p=26}} * ''c.'' 7630 BCE - The sloth ''[[Catonyx|Catonyx cuvieri]]'' survived in [[Brazil]] until about this time.<ref name="Haynes"/><ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 7490 BCE - ''[[Megalonyx|Megalonyx jeffersonii]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Kurten"/> * ''c.'' 7490 BCE - The stilt-legged deer ''[[Sangamona]]'' survived in [[Missouri]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=75}} * ''c.'' 7470 BCE - The [[Cyprus dwarf elephant]] became extinct around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 7460 BCE - The peccary ''[[Mylohyus]]'' survived in [[Tennessee]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} ''[[Smilodon|Smilodon fatalis]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Kurten"/> * ''c.'' 7450 BCE - The [[dire wolf]] ''Canis dirus'' survived in Missouri until about this time. Its extinction was probably caused by competition with ''Canis lupus'', the extant [[gray wolf]].{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=55}} * ''c.'' 7290 BCE - The [[Cyprus dwarf hippopotamus]] became extinct at about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 7180 BCE - ''[[Smilodon|Smilodon populator]]'' survived in [[Brazil]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==7th millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 6960 BCE - ''[[Scelidodon|Scelidodon chiliensis]]'' survived in [[Peru]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 6910 BCE - The [[steppe bison|primitive bison]] survived in the [[Taymyr Peninsula]] until this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 6730 BCE - ''[[Columbian mammoth|Mammuthus columbi]]'' survived in [[Saskatchewan]] until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=100}} ''[[Equus (genus)|Equus santaelenae]]'' survived in [[Ecuador]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 6720 BCE - ''[[Pika#Extinct pikas|Ochotona whartoni]]'' survived in eastern North America until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 6689 BCE - ''[[Mylodon]]'' survived in Chile until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=54}} * ''c.'' 6577 BCE - ''[[Hemiauchenia]]'' survived in Nevada until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} * ''c.'' 6290 BCE - The camel ''[[Camelops]]'' survived in Arizona until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=446}} * ''c.'' 6275 BCE - ''[[Bubo (bird)|Bubo insularis]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 6050 BCE - ''[[Megalotragus|Megalotragus priscus]]'' survived in [[South Africa]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==6th millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 5914 BCE - The [[Cuban pauraque]] survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 5620 BCE - ''[[Antilopinae|Antidorcas bondi]]'' survived in [[South Africa]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 5370 BCE - ''[[Megatherium|Megatherium americanum]]'' survived in [[Argentina]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 5020 BCE - The Sardinian giant deer ''[[Praemegaceros|Praemegaceros cazioti]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==5th millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 4950 BCE - ''[[Dactylopsila|Dactylopsila kambuaya]]'' and ''[[Pseudocheiridae|Petauroides ayamaruensis]]'' survived in [[New Guinea]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 4866 BCE - [[Irish elk]] survived in the [[Ural Mountains|Urals]] and western [[Siberia]] until this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 4605 BCE - The [[glyptodontidae|glyptodont]] ''[[Doedicurus|Doedicurus clavicaudatus]]'' survived in [[Argentina]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 4180 BCE - ''[[Ibiza rail|Rallus eivissensis]]'' survived on [[Ibiza]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>

==3rd millennium BCE== [[File:Brehms Het Leven der Dieren Zoogdieren Orde 4 Leeuw (Felis leo capensis).jpg|thumb|right| Cave lion]] * ''c.'' 2915 BCE - The canid ''[[Dusicyon|Dusicyon avus]]'' survived in Argentina until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 2835 BCE - The [[Myotragus|Balearic cave goat]] became extinct around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 2765 BCE - The [[North Africa]]n buffalo ''[[Pelorovis|Pelorovis antiquus]]'' survived until about this time. Its extinction may have been caused by competition for food and water with domestic [[cattle]].<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 2550 BCE - The [[Bennu heron]] became extinct around this time, possibly due to degradation of its wetland habitat. It was last recorded in the [[Arabian Peninsula]].<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 2441 BCE - The sloth ''[[Neocnus|Neocnus comes]]'' survived in [[Haiti]] until about this time.<ref name="Steadman2005"/> * ''c.'' 2240 BCE - The sloth ''[[Megalocnus|Megalocnus rodens]]'' and the [[Nesotrochis|Cuban cave rail]] survived in [[Cuba]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==2nd millennium BCE== * ''c.'' 1900 BCE - ''[[Hispaniola monkey|Antillothrix bernensis]]'' survived on Hispaniola until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1780 BCE - The last known population of [[woolly mammoth]]s on [[Wrangel Island]] died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.<ref name="Haynes" /><ref name="Turvey"/><ref name="Adams">{{cite book|title=Species richness: patterns in the diversity of life|last=Adams|first=Jonathan|author2=Adams, Jonathan S.|year=2009|publisher=Springer|isbn=3-540-74277-8|pages=239–55|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fPAO6kfbizMC&dq=wrangel+island+mammoth&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=28 February 2012}}</ref> * ''c.'' 1520 BCE - The [[Sylviornis|giant flightless megapode]] survived on [[New Caledonia]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1380 BCE - ''[[Acratocnus|Acratocnus odontrigonus]]'', formerly inhabiting Puerto Rico and [[Antigua]], survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1300 BCE - ''[[Thylogale|Thylogale christenseni]]'' survived in New Guinea until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>

''[[Microgale|Microgale macpheei]]'' survived in [[Madagascar]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 457 BCE - The rodent ''[[Plate-toothed giant hutia|Elasmodontomys obliquus]]'' survived in [[Puerto Rico]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Turvey | first1 = S.T | last2 = Oliver | first2 = J.R | last3 = Storde | first3 = Y.M Narganes | last4 = Rye | first4 = P | date = April 22, 2007 | title = Late Holocene extinction of Puerto Rican native land mammals. | journal = [[Biology Letters]] | volume = 3 | issue = 2 | page = 193–196 | doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2006.0585 | pmid=17251123 | pmc=2375922}}</ref> * ''c.'' 450 BCE - ''[[Crocidura|Crocidura balsamifera]]'' survived in [[Egypt]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 341 BCE - ''[[Archaeoindris|Archaeoindris fontoynonti]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 195 BCE - ''[[Jamaican monkey|Xenothrix mcgregori]]'' survived until about this time.<ref name="Cooke2011">{{cite journal | last1 = Cooke | first1 = Siobhán B. | last2 = Rosenberger | first2 = Alfred L. | last3 = Turvey | first3 = Samuel | date = February 15, 2011 | title = An extinct monkey from Haiti and the origins of the Greater Antillean primates | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 108 | issue = 7 | page = 2699–2704 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1009161108 | pmid=21282603 | pmc=3041101}}</ref> * ''c.'' 110 BCE - ''[[Archaeolemur|Archaeolemur edwardsi]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 100 BCE - [[Syrian elephant]] becomes extinct due to overhunting for ivory.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Choudhury, A., Lahiri Choudhury, D.K., Desai, A., Duckworth, J.W., Easa, P.S., Johnsingh, A.J.T., Fernando, P., Hedges, S., Gunawardena, M., Kurt, F., Karanth, U., Lister, A., Menon, V., Riddle, H., Rübel, A. & Wikramanayake, E. (IUCN SSC Asian Elephant Specialist Group) | title = ''Elephas maximus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T7140A12828813 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/7140/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T7140A12828813.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * ''c.'' 30 BCE - ''[[Coua|Coua primaeva]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==1st millennium ''[[Common Era|CE]]''==
===2nd century=== * ''c.'' 100 - The [[Apteribis|Maui highland apteribis]] survived on [[Maui]] until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===3rd century=== * ''c.'' 200 - The [[Lowland kagu|coastal kagu]], [[Kanaka pigeon]], [[New Caledonian gallinule]], [[pile-builder megapode]], and [[powerful goshawk]] survived until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 256 - ''[[Mesopropithecus|Mesopropithecus globiceps]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===5th century=== * ''c.'' 450 - The turtle genus ''[[Meiolania]]'' survived until this time on [[New Caledonia]].<ref name="MacPhee">{{cite book|title=Extinctions in near time: causes, contexts, and consequences|last=MacPhee|first=R.D. E.|year=1999|publisher=Springer|isbn=0-306-46092-0|pages=19–28, 394|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UZLuF1YXYTcC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=29 February 2012}}</ref>
===6th century=== * ''c.'' 537 - ''[[Hadropithecus|Hadropithecus stenognathus]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 540 - ''[[Mesopropithecus|Mesopropithecus pithecoides]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 570 - ''[[Malagasy shelduck|Alopochen sirabensis]]'' survived in Madagascar until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===7th century=== * ''c.'' 685 - The [[lava shearwater]] survived until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===8th century=== * ''c.'' 730 - ''[[Pachylemur|Pachylemur insignis]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 731 - The rodent ''[[Insular cave rat|Heteropsomys insulans]]'' survived in Puerto Rico until about this time.<ref name="Turvey2007"/>
===9th century=== * ''c.'' 836 - The [[coastal moa]] survived in New Zealand until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 885 - ''[[Giant aye-aye|Daubentonia robusta]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===10th century=== * ''c.'' 900 - The [[nene-nui]] survived on Maui until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 915 - ''[[Plesiorycteropus]]'' survived in Madagascar until about this time.{{Sfn|Martin|Klein|1989|p=82}} * ''c.'' 950 - [[Sinoto's lorikeet]] and the [[conquered lorikeet]] survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 996 - The [[New Zealand owlet-nightjar]] survived until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
==2nd millennium CE==
===12th century=== * ''c.'' 1180 - The [[Maui Nui moa-nalo]] survived until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> The [[moa-nalo]] were large ducks and the Hawaiian Islands' major herbivores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wylie|first=Robin|title=Hawaii: The islands where evolution ran riot|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20150625-islands-where-evolution-ran-riot|publisher=bbc|date=June 25, 2015}}</ref> * ''c.'' 1190 - The [[Hunter Island penguin]] survived until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/>
===14th century=== * ''c.'' 1320 - The lemur ''[[Koala lemur|Megaladapis edwardsi]]'' survived in [[Madagascar]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1322 - The [[upland moa]] survived in [[New Zealand]]'s [[South Island]] until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1326 - [[Mantell's moa]] survived in [[New Zealand]]'s [[North Island]] until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1360 - ''[[Nesophontes]]'' survived in [[Cuba]] until around this time.<ref name="Haynes"/>
===15th century=== * ''c.'' 1400 - [[New Zealand]]'s [[Haast's eagle]], a giant bird of prey, becomes extinct. The eagle's main prey were various species of [[moa]], which also went extinct.<ref>BBC (2009). [https://web.archive.org/web/20090228152921/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/wildfacts/factfiles/3044.shtml '' "Harpagornis moorei (Haast's eagle)" ''], archive.org/BBC; retrieved 19 June 2017</ref> * ''c.'' 1420 - The [[South Island giant moa]] survived in [[New Zealand]]'s South Island until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> * ''c.'' 1440 - The lemur ''[[Palaeopropithecus|Palaeopropithecus ingens]]'' survived in [[Madagascar]] until about this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> *The [[moa]]s of [[New Zealand]] became extinct, probably due to hunting.<ref name="Adams"/>
===16th century=== * ''c.'' 1500-1550 - The [[Waitaha penguin]] of [[New Zealand]]'s [[South Island]] became extinct.<ref name="Hume"/>
===17th century=== *1627 - The last known [[aurochs]] died in [[Poland]]. This large wild cattle formerly inhabited much of Europe, northern Africa, the Middle East, central Asia, and [[India]].<ref name="aurochs">{{Cite journal | author = Tikhonov, A. | title = ''Bos primigenius'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T136721A4332142 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/136721/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T136721A4332142.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * ''c.'' 1645 - [[Finsch's duck]] survived in New Zealand until around this time.<ref name="Turvey"/> *1662 - The last definite sighting of a [[dodo]] was made in [[Mauritius]].<ref name="Adams"/> The extinction was due to hunting, but also by the pigs, rats, dogs and cats brought to the island by settlers. The species has become an iconic symbol of animal extinction.<ref>[http://www.petermaas.nl/extinct/speciesinfo/dodobird.htm Raphus cucullatus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514014631/http://www.petermaas.nl/extinct/speciesinfo/dodobird.htm |date=14 May 2007 }} at the Recently Extinct Animals website</ref>[[File:Moa bw.jpg|thumb|The moa was one of the largest birds that ever existed.]] *The [[elephant bird]] ''[[Aepyornis maximus]]'' was last recorded around the end of the 17th century.<ref name="Hume">{{cite book|title=Extinct Birds|last=Hume|first=Julian P.|author2=Walters, Michael|year=2012|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=1-4081-5862-0|pages=24, 59, 320|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fPAO6kfbizMC&dq=wrangel+island+mammoth&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=28 February 2012}}</ref>
===18th century=== *1768 - [[Steller's sea cow]] became extinct due to overhunting for meat and leather.<ref name="Turvey"/><ref name="steller">{{IUCN2010|id=10303|title=Hydrodamalis gigas|downloaded=10 July 2014|version=2011.2|year=2008|assessor=Domning, D.|assessor2=Anderson, P.K.|assessor3=Turvey, S.|last-assessor-amp=yes}}</ref> *1773 - The [[Tahiti sandpiper]] died out after rats were introduced to its habitat in the [[Society Islands]].<ref>BirdLife International (2008). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003033/0 ''"Prosobonia leucoptera (Tahitian Sandpiper)"''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 29 February 2012.</ref> *1774 - The [[Sardinian pika]] became extinct due to invasive species (foxes, cats, etc.) that were introduced to [[Sardinia]] and [[Corsica]].<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Smith, A.T. & Johnston, C.H. | title = ''Prolagus sardus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T18338A8103116 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/18338/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T18338A8103116.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1777 - The [[Society parakeet]] population dies out on the Society Islands after vessels released pests.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Cyanoramphus ulietanus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22728673A94993704 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22728673/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22728673A94993704.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1790 - The [[Lord Howe swamphen]], also known as the white gallinule, becomes extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Porphyrio albus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22692801A93370193 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22692801/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22692801A93370193.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
===19th century=== *1800 - The last known [[bluebuck]] was shot, making the species the first African antelope to be hunted to extinction by European settlers.<ref>IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group (2008). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/10168/0 ''"Hippotragus leucophaeus (Bluebuck, Blue Buck)"''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 29 February 2012.</ref> *1825 - The [[mysterious starling]] died out.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Aplonis mavornata'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22710499A94248417 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22710499/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22710499A94248417.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1826 - The [[Mauritius blue pigeon]] becomes extinct due to excessive hunting.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Alectroenas nitidissimus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22691601A93318208 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22691601/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22691601A93318208.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1827 - The [[Tonga ground skink]] dies out from its only home in the Tongan Islands.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Allison, A., Hamilton, A. & Tallowin, O. | title = ''Tachygyia microlepis'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2012 | page = e.T21286A2775072 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2012 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/21286/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2012.RLTS.T21286A2775072.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> [[File:Quagga (Equus Quagga).png|thumb|Quagga]]
*1852 - The last sighting of a [[great auk]] was made off the coast of [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]]. The bird was driven to extinction by hunting for its fat, feathers, meat, and oil.<ref name="Adams"/><ref>BirdLife International (2008). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003305/0 ''"Pinguinus impennis (Great Auk)"''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 29 February 2012.</ref> *1860 - The [[string tree]] from the island of [[St Helena]] becomes extinct because of habitat destruction.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Lambdon, P.W. & Ellick, S. | title = ''Acalypha rubrinervis'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T37854A67371775 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/37854/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-1.RLTS.T37854A67371775.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1860 - The [[sea mink]] becomes extinct because of hunting for its fur.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Helgen, K. & Turvey, S.T. | title = ''Neovison macrodon'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T40784A45204492 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/40784/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-1.RLTS.T40784A45204492.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1875 - The [[broad-faced potoroo]] was last recorded.<ref name="Turvey"/> *1876 - The [[Falkland Islands wolf]] became extinct.<ref name="Turvey"/> *1878 - [[Labrador duck]] declared extinct after last appearances in [[Long Island]] three years earlier.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Camptorhynchus labradorius'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22680418A92862623 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22680418/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22680418A92862623.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * ''c.'' 1879 - The last known [[Atlas bear]], Africa's only native bear, is killed by hunters in [[Morocco]]. The bear was heavily hunted and used for sport in the Roman Empire.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ursus arctos crowtheri|url=http://www.prehistoric-wildlife.com/species/u/ursus-arctos-crowtheri-atlas-bear.html|publisher=Prehistoric Wildlife|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> *1880 - The [[eastern elk]], a subspecies of elk in the US and Canada, is declared extinct.<ref>U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (2016). [https://www.fws.gov/midwest/endangered/lists/extinct.html'' "Cervus canadensis canadensis (Eastern Elk)" ''], fws.gov; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> *1883 - The [[Quagga]], a sub-species of the [[plains zebra]], goes extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = King, S.R.B. & Moehlman, P.D. | title = ''Equus quagga'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T41013A45172424 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41013/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-2.RLTS.T41013A45172424.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1886 - The red alga known as [[Bennett's seaweed]] from Australia disappears because of the massive human activities.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Millar, A.J.K. ===20th century===
====1900s==== *1902 - The last known specimens of the [[Rocky Mountain locust]] are collected near [[Brandon, Manitoba|Brandon]], Manitoba.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Mysterious Disappearance of the Rocky Mountain Locust|url=http://www.bozeman-magpie.com/thebigmt-full-article.php?article_id=696|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> *1905 - The last known [[Honshū wolf]] of Japan dies in Nara Prefecture.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Honshu Wolf|url=http://bib.ge/wolf/open.php?id=1094|publisher=bib.ge|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> *1907 - The [[huia]], a native bird of New Zealand, is last seen. Habitat loss, hunting, and disease all played a role in its extinction.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Heteralocha acutirostris'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2017 | page = e.T22708091A119257859 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22708091/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2017-3.RLTS.T22708091A119257859.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1909 - The last known [[tarpan]], a Polish wild horse, died in captivity.<ref>Bunzel-Drüke, M., C. Böhm, P. Finck, G. Kämmer, R. Luick, E. Reisinger, U. Riecken, J. Riedl, M. Scharf & O. Zimball: “Wilde Weiden. Praxisleitfaden für Ganzjahresbeweidung in Naturschutz und Landschaftsentwicklung.” Bad Sassendorf-Lohne: Arbeitsgemeinschaft Biologischer Umweltschutz im Kreis Soest e.V., 2008. ([http://www.abu-naturschutz.de/images/wildeweiden/WildeWeiden.pdf pdf, 300 MB])</ref>
====1910s==== *1911 - The last [[Newfoundland wolf]] was shot.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1914 - The last [[passenger pigeon]], Martha, died in captivity at the [[Cincinnati Zoo]]. Excessive hunting contributed to its extinction; it was formerly one of the world's most abundant birds.<ref>{{IUCN|id=22690733|title=''Ectopistes migratorius''|assessor=BirdLife International|assessor-link=BirdLife International|version=2013.2|year=2012|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> *1918 - The last [[Carolina parakeet]] died in captivity at the Cincinnati Zoo. The bird, formerly inhabiting the southeastern United States, was driven to extinction by exploitation, deforestation, and competition with introduced [[bee]]s.<ref>{{IUCN|id=22685776|title=''Conuropsis carolinensis''|assessor=BirdLife International|assessor-link=BirdLife International|version=2013.2|year=2012|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>
====1920s==== *1924 - The [[California grizzly bear]] is sighted for the last time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Grizzly Bear|url=https://www.vchistory.org/exhibits/grizzly-bear/|publisher=Valley Center History Museum|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> *1925 - The [[Kenai Peninsula wolf]] was driven to extinction.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1929 - ''[[Acalypha wilderi]]'' was last seen in the wild. This species may be synonymous with ''[[Acalypha raivavensis|A. raivavensis]]'' and ''[[Acalypha tubuaiensis|A. tubuaiensis]]'', which would mean it is in fact not extinct globally.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = de Lange, P., Martin, T. & McCormack, G. | title = ''Acalypha wilderi'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2014 | page = e.T199821A2612719 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2014 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/199821/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2014-1.RLTS.T199821A2612719.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
====1930s==== *1930 - [[Nesoryzomys darwini|Darwin's rice rat]] was last recorded in the [[Galápagos Islands]]. Its extinction was probably caused by the introduction of [[black rat]]s.<ref name="nesoryzomys">{{Cite journal | author = Tirira, D., Dowler, R., Boada, C. & Weksler, M. | title = ''Nesoryzomys darwini'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T14706A4456400 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/14706/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T14706A4456400.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1932 - "Booming Ben", the last known [[heath hen]] was seen on [[Martha's Vineyard]], Massachusetts.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Tympanuchus cupido'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22679514A92817099 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22679514/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22679514A92817099.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref><ref>Rebecca Heisman (2016). [https://daily.jstor.org/last-heath-hen/ '' "Tympanuchus cupido cupido (Heath Hen)" ''], jstor.org; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> *1933 - The [[cry pansy]] from Europe becomes extinct due to habitat loss and overcollection in the only place where it grew, France.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Juillet, N. | title = ''Viola cryana'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2011 | page = e.T165210A5990668 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2011 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/165210/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2011-1.RLTS.T165210A5990668.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1934 - The [[Nesoryzomys indefessus|indefatigable Galapagos mouse]] was last recorded. Its extinction was probably caused by the introduction of [[black rat]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Tirira, D., Dowler, R., Boada, C. & Weksler, M. | title = ''Nesoryzomys indefessus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T14708A4456597 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/14708/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T14708A4456597.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1935 - The [[desert rat-kangaroo]] was last recorded.<ref name="Turvey"/> *1935 - The [[Mogollon mountain wolf]] and the [[Southern Rocky Mountains wolf]] were hunted to extinction.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1936 - The last [[thylacine]] died in captivity. Hunting, habitat loss, disease, and competition from domestic dogs all may have contributed to the extinction of the species.<ref name="thylacine">{{IUCN2010|id=21866|title=Thylacinus cynocephalus|downloaded=23 July 2010|version=2011.2|year=2008|assessor=M. McKnight}}</ref> * c. 1937 - The [[Bali tiger]] was last definitively seen around this time, but likely persisted into the 1940s or possibly even the early 1950s.<ref>Jackson, P. & Nowell, K. (2008). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41682/0 '' "Panthera tigris balica (Bali Tiger)" ''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> *1939 - The [[toolache wallaby]] was last recorded.<ref name="Turvey"/> [[File:Pinguinus impennis.jpg|thumb|The [[great auk]] was hunted for its [[Down feather|down]] until its extinction around 1844.]]
[[File:Thylacine (Krefft).jpg|thumb|The thylacine was exterminated into extinction.]]
====1940s==== *1940 - The [[Cascade mountain wolf]] was hunted to extinction.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1942 - The [[Texas wolf]] was purposefully driven to extinction.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1942 - The last confirmed sighting of the [[Barbary lion]], although unconfirmed reports surfaced until 1970.<ref name="Barbary Lion Extinction">{{cite web|title=Examining the Extinction of the Barbary Lion and Its Implications for Felid Conservation|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0060174|publisher=PLOS ONE|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
====1950s==== *1952 - Last reliable report of the [[Caribbean monk seal]].<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Lowry, L. | title = ''Neomonachus tropicalis'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2015 | page = e.T13655A45228171 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2015 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/13655/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2015-2.RLTS.T13655A45228171.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1952 - The [[Bernard's wolf]] was hunted to extinction.<ref name="wolfhowl.org"/> *1956 - The [[crescent nail-tail wallaby]] and [[imperial woodpecker]] were last recorded.<ref name="Turvey"/> *1957 - The [[Scioto madtom]], a species of fish, is last collected.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = NatureServe | title = ''Noturus trautmani'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2013 | page = e.T14908A19032932 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2013 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/14908/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2013-1.RLTS.T14908A19032932.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
====1960s==== * c. 1960 - The [[Mexican grizzly bear]] was exterminated around this time.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = McLellan, B.N., Proctor, M.F., Huber, D. & Michel, S | title = ''Ursus arctos'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2017 | page = e.T41688A121229971 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41688/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2017-3.RLTS.T41688A121229971.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1962 - The [[red-bellied gracile opossum]] was last recorded in [[Argentina]].<ref name="Turvey"/> * 1964 - The [[Hawaii chaff flower]] of the Hawaiian islands becomes extinct because of habitat loss.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Bruegmann, M.M. & Caraway, V. | title = ''Achyranthes atollensis'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2003 | page = e.T44074A10847953 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2003 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/44074/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2003.RLTS.T44074A10847953.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * 1965 - Last sighting of the [[turgid-blossom pearly mussel]], an American mussel.<ref name=mussel>{{Cite news|title=Three American mussel species become extinct |url=http://news.mongabay.com/2008/0810-hance_mussels.html |publisher=mongabay.com |date=10 August 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107225640/http://news.mongabay.com/2008/0810-hance_mussels.html |archivedate=7 January 2010 }}</ref> * 1966 - The last [[Arabian ostrich]] died around this time.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Struthio camelus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T45020636A95139620 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/45020636/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T45020636A95139620.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
====1970s==== * c. 1970 - The [[Caspian tiger]] becomes extinct primarily due to habitat loss, hunting, and loss of prey.<ref>Jackson, P. & Nowell, K. (2011). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41505/0 '' "Panthera tigris virgate (Caspian Tiger)" ''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> * 1972 - The endemic to Jamaica [[Mason River myrtle]] becomes extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Kelly, D.L. | title = ''Myrcia skeldingii'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 1998 | page = e.T33796A9805664 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 1998 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/33796/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.1998.RLTS.T33796A9805664.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * 1974 - The last known [[Japanese sea lion]] is captured off the coast of [[Rebun Island]], [[Hokkaido]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Zalophus californianus japonicus (CR)|url=http://www.biodic.go.jp/cgi-db/gen/RDB_G2000_DO.RDB_DETAIL?wamei=%a5%cb%a5%db%a5%f3%a5%a2%a5%b7%a5%ab|publisher=Japanese Ministry of the Environment|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> * c. 1976 - Last sightings of the [[Javan tiger]].<ref>Jackson, P. & Nowell, K. (2008). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41681/0 '' "Panthera tigris sondaica (Javan Tiger)" ''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref>
====1980s==== *1981 - The [[Puhielelu hibiscadelphus]] becomes extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = World Conservation Monitoring Centre | title = ''Hibiscadelphus crucibracteatus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 1998 | page = e.T33556A9793280 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 1998 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/33556/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.1998.RLTS.T33556A9793280.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1981 - Last sighting of the [[Epioblasma torulosa|green-blossom pearly mussel]], an American mussel.<ref>Bogan, A.E. (Mollusc Specialist Group) (2000). [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/7886/0 '' "Epioblasma torulosa gubernaculum (Green-Blossom Pearly Mussel)" ''], iucnredlist.org; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> * 1981 - The [[Gastric-brooding frog|Southern gastric-brooding frog]] (''Rheobatrachus silus'') became extinct probably due to habitat destruction and disease.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Ed Meyer, David Newell, Harry Hines, Sarah May, Jean-Marc Hero, John Clarke, Frank Lemckert | title = ''Rheobatrachus silus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2004 | page = e.T19475A8896430 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2004 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/19475/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2004.RLTS.T19475A8896430.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> * 1983 - Last unconfirmed spotting of the [[kouprey]] (''Bos sauveli''),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wildcattleconservation.org/WildCattleNews/wildcattlenews06.html#news052006|title=Search for the kouprey: trail runs cold for Cambodia’s national animal | publisher=Phnom Penh Post, April 2006}}</ref> last absolute confirmed spotting was in 1969/70.<ref name=iucn-kouprey>{{IUCN2008|assessor=Timmins, R.J.|assessor2=Hedges, S.|assessor3=Duckworth., J.W.|last-assessor-amp=yes|year=2008|id=2890|title=Bos sauveli|downloaded=5 September 2016}}.</ref> Declared as “most likely to be extinct” by the IUCN.<ref name=iucn-kouprey /> *1983-84 - The [[Heliaster solaris|24-rayed sunstar]] (''Heliaster solaris''), the Galapagos black-spotted damselfish and the Galapagos stringweed likely become extinct due to [[climate change]].<ref name=galapagos>{{Cite news|last=Hance|first=Jeremy|title=Extinctions on the rise in the Galapagos: fishing and global warming devastating islands’ species|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2009/1203-hance_galapagos.html|publisher=mongabay.com|date=3 December 2009|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> * 1985 - The [[gastric-brooding frog|Northern gastric-brooding frog]] (''Rheobatrachus vitellinus'') became extinct probably due to habitat destruction and disease.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Jean-Marc Hero, Keith McDonald, Ross Alford, Michael Cunningham, Richard Retallick | title = ''Rheobatrachus vitellinus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2004 | page = e.T19476A8897826 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2004 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/19476/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2004.RLTS.T19476A8897826.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1987 - The last [[Kauaʻi ʻōʻō]] (''Moho braccatus)'', a male, is recorded singing a mating call. The species was never heard from again and was declared extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Moho braccatus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T22704323A93963628 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/22704323/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T22704323A93963628.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1989 - The [[golden toad]] of Costa Rica becomes extinct, perhaps because of [[climate change]].<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Savage, J., Pounds, J. & Bolaños, F. | title = ''Incilius periglenes'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T3172A9654595 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/3172/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T3172A9654595.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
====1990s==== *1990 - The [[dusky seaside sparrow]] was officially declared extinct in December 1990. The last definite known individual died on 17 June 1987.<ref>U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (2014). [https://www.fws.gov/refuge/St_Johns/wildlife_and_habitat/dusky_seaside_sparrow.html '' "Ammodramus maritimus nigrescens (Dusky Seaside Sparrow)" ''], fws.gov; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> *1994 - [[Saint Croix racer]], a snake native to the [[Virgin Islands]], declared extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Platenberg, R. & Powell, R. | title = ''Borikenophis sanctaecrucis'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T40791A115177079 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/40791/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T40791A71740001.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1994 - [[Levuana moth]] from Hawaii goes extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = World Conservation Monitoring Centre | title = ''Levuana irridescens'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 1996 | page = e.T11919A3315160 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 1996 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/11919/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.1996.RLTS.T11919A3315160.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *1997 - The [[Hainan ormosia]] (a species of legume) which was native to [[China]] is no longer seen.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = World Conservation Monitoring Centre | title = ''Ormosia howii'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 1998 | page = e.T32433A9706669 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 1998 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/32433/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.1998.RLTS.T32433A9706669.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref>
==3rd millennium CE== ===21st century===
====2000s==== *2000 - "Celia", the last [[Pyrenean ibex]], was found dead in 2000. However, in 2003, a female was cloned back into existence, but died shortly after birth due to defects in the lungs.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Herrero, J. & Pérez, J.M | title = ''Capra pyrenaica'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T3798A10085397 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/3798/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T3798A10085397.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref><ref>Carl Zimmer (2013). [http://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2013/04/species-revival-bringing-back-extinct-animals/ '' "Capra pyrenaica pyrenaica (Pyrenean Ibex)" ''], nationalgeographic.com; retrieved 23 June 2017.</ref> *2003 - The last individual from the [[St. Helena olive]], which was grown in cultivation, dies off. The last plant in the wild had died in 1994.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Lambdon, P.W. & Ellick, S. | title = ''Nesiota elliptica'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T37598A67372241 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/37598/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-1.RLTS.T37598A67372241.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *2006 - A technologically sophisticated survey of the Yangtze River failed to find specimens of the [[baiji dolphin]], prompting scientists to declare it functionally extinct.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/12119/0|title=Lipotes vexillifer|date=February 2012|accessdate=6 February 2013|publisher=IUCN Red List}}</ref>
====2010s==== *2011 - The [[Eastern cougar]] was declared extinct. Last known individual was trapped and killed in 1938.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/02/eastern-cougar-declared-extinct-confirming-decades-of-suspicion/|title=Eastern cougar declared extinct, confirming decades of suspicion|date=2 March 2011|accessdate=14 November 2011|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/jun/17/eastern-cougar-extinct-no-longer-needs-protection-says-us-conservation-agency|title=Eastern Cougar extinct, no longer needs protection, says US conservation agency|date=17 June 2015|accessdate=3 December 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref> *2011 - The [[western black rhinoceros]] was declared extinct.<ref>{{cite news|title=Western black rhino declared extinct|first=Daniel|last= Boettcher|publisher=bbc|accessdate=27 April 2016|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15663982}}</ref> *2012 - The [[Japanese river otter]] (''Lutra lutra whiteneyi'') declared extinct by the country's Ministry of the Environment, after not being seen for more than 30 years.<ref>Environment Ministry (2012). [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2012/08/29/news/japanese-river-otter-declared-extinct/#.WVlbxWYVDIU '' "Lutra lutra whiteneyi (Japanese River Otter)" ''], japantimes.co.jp; retrieved 02 July 2017.</ref> *2012 - "[[Lonesome George]]", the last known specimen of the [[Pinta Island tortoise]], died on 24 June 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lonesome George|url=http://www.galapagos.org/about_galapagos/about-galapagos/lonesome-george/|publisher=Galapagos Conservancy}}</ref> *2013 - The [[Cape Verde giant skink]] was declared extinct.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Vasconcelos, R. | title = ''Chioninia coctei'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2013 | page = e.T13152363A13152374 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2013 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/13152363/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2013-1.RLTS.T13152363A13152374.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *2013 - The [[Formosan clouded leopard]], previously endemic to the island of [[Taiwan]], is officially declared extinct.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clouded leopards declared extinct in Taiwan|publisher=Tree Hugger|date=6 May 2013|url=http://www.treehugger.com/endangered-species/clouded-leopards-declared-extinct-taiwan.html|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> *2014 - The [[Bermuda saw-whet owl]] was declared extinct after being described from fossils in 2012.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = BirdLife International | title = ''Aegolius gradyi'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2016 | page = e.T62184893A95192681 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2016 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/62184893/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-3.RLTS.T62184893A95192681.en | access-date = 16 January 2018}}</ref> *2016 - The [[Bramble Cay melomys]] was declared extinct.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2016-2.RLTS.T13132A97448475.en|title=Melomys rubicola. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2016|last=Woinarski, J. & Burbidge, A.A.|first=|date=2016|website=IUCN|access-date=7 March 2017}}</ref> *2017 - The [[Christmas Island forest skink]] was declared extinct, three years after the last known specimen died.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2017-3.RLTS.T178595A101749951.en|title=Emoia natavitatis. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2017|last=Cogger, H. & Woinarski, J.|first=|date=2017|publisher=IUCN|access-date=24 October 2018}}</ref>

{{pp-pc1}} {{Italic title}} {{speciesbox | name = Immortal jellyfish | image = Turritopsis dohrnii.jpg | image_caption = ''Turritopsis dohrnii'' medusa | genus = Turritopsis | species = dohrnii | authority = ([[August Weismann|Weismann]], 1883)<ref>{{cite WoRMS |year=2012 |title=''Turritopsis dorhnii'' (Weissmann, 1883) |db=Hydrozoa |id=151801 |accessdate=November 29, 2012}}</ref> }}
'''''Turritopsis dohrnii''''', the '''immortal jellyfish''', is a [[species]] of small, [[biological immortality|biologically immortal]] [[jellyfish]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bavestrello|first=Giorgio |author2=Christian Sommer |author3=Michele Sarà|year=1992|title=Bi-directional conversion in Turritopsis nutricula (Hydrozoa)|journal=Scientia Marina|volume=56|issue=2–3|pages=137–140}}</ref><ref name="piraino-96">{{cite journal|last=Piraino|first=Stefano|author2=F. Boero |author3=B. Aeschbach |author4=V. Schmid |year=1996|title=Reversing the life cycle: medusae transforming into polyps and cell transdifferentiation in Turritopsis nutricula (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa)|journal=Biological Bulletin|volume=190|issue=3|pages=302–312|doi=10.2307/1543022|pmid=29227703|jstor=1543022}}</ref> found in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and in the waters of [[Japan]]. It is one of the few known cases of [[animal]]s capable of reverting completely to a sexually immature, colonial stage after having reached sexual maturity as a solitary individual. Others include the jellyfish ''{{ill|Laodicea undulata|sv}}''<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Evidence of reverse development in Leptomedusae (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa): the case of Laodicea undulata (Forbes and Goodsir 1851)|last = De Vito|date = 2006|journal = Marine Biology|doi = 10.1007/s00227-005-0182-3|pmid = |display-authors=etal|volume=149|issue = 2|pages=339–346}}</ref> and ''[[Aurelia (genus)|Aurelia]]'' sp.1.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Life Cycle Reversal in Aurelia sp.1 (Cnidaria, Scyphozoa)|last = He|date = 2015-12-21|journal = PLoS ONE|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0145314|pmid = 26690755|display-authors=etal|volume=10|issue = 12|pmc=4687044|pages=e0145314}}</ref>
Like most other [[hydrozoan]]s, ''T. dohrnii'' begin their life as free-swimming tiny [[larva]]e known as [[planula]]. As a planula settles down, it gives rise to a colony of [[polyp]]s that are attached to the sea-floor. All the polyps and jellyfish arising from a single planula are genetically identical clones. The polyps form into an extensively branched form, which is not commonly seen in most jellyfish. Jellyfish, also known as medusae, then bud off these polyps and continue their life in a free-swimming form, eventually becoming sexually mature. When sexually mature they have been known to prey on other jellyfish species at a rapid pace. If a ''T. dohrnii'' jellyfish is exposed to environmental stress or physical assault, or is sick or old, it can revert to the polyp stage, forming a new polyp colony.<ref name=nytm/> It does this through the cell development process of [[transdifferentiation]], which alters the [[cellular differentiation|differentiated state of the cells]] and transforms them into new types of cells.
Theoretically, this process can go on indefinitely, effectively rendering the jellyfish biologically immortal,<ref name="piraino-96"/><ref name="CheatingDeath">{{cite web|url=http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6|title=Cheating Death: The Immortal Life Cycle of Turritopsis|last=Gilbert|first=Scott F.|year=2006|accessdate=2009-03-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402085711/http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6|archivedate=2010-04-02|df=}}</ref> although in practice individuals can still die. In nature, most ''Turritopsis'' are likely to succumb to predation or disease in the medusa stage, without reverting to the polyp form.<ref name="National Geographic News">{{cite web |title="Immortal" Jellyfish Swarm World's Oceans |author=Ker Than |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/01/090130-immortal-jellyfish-swarm.html |date=January 29, 2009 |publisher=[[National Geographic News]] |accessdate=2010-06-16 }}</ref>
The capability of biological immortality with no maximum lifespan makes ''T. dohrnii'' an important target of basic biological, [[Ageing|aging]] and [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceutical]] research.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencepub.net/stem/stem0504/007_A00288stem050414_49_53.pdf|doi=10.7537/marsscj050414.07}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
The "immortal jellyfish" was formerly classified as ''[[Turritopsis nutricula|T. nutricula]]''.<ref name=mig/>
== Description ==
The medusa of ''Turritopsis dohrnii'' is bell-shaped, with a maximum diameter of about {{convert|4.5|mm|in}} and is about as tall as it is wide.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kramp|first=P. L.|title=Synopsis of the medusae of the world|journal=Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom|year=1961|volume=40|pages=1–469|doi=10.1017/s0025315400007347}}</ref><ref name="TimesOnline26012009" /> The jelly in the walls of the bell is uniformly thin, except for some thickening at the apex. The relatively large stomach is bright red and has a cruciform shape in cross section. Young specimens 1 mm in diameter have only eight tentacles evenly spaced out along the edge,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Martell|first=L.|last2=Piraino|first2=S.|last3=Gravili|first3=C.|last4=Boero|first4=F.|date=2016-07-02|title=Life cycle, morphology and medusa ontogenesis of Turritopsis dohrnii (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa)|journal=Italian Journal of Zoology|volume=83|issue=3|pages=390–399|doi=10.1080/11250003.2016.1203034|issn=1125-0003}}</ref> whereas adult specimens have 80–90 tentacles. The medusa (jellyfish) is free-living in the plankton. Dense [[nerve net]] cells are also present in the [[epidermis]] in the cap. They form a large ring-like structure above the radial cannal which is commonly presented in cnidarians.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Koizumi|first=Osamu|last2=Hamada|first2=Shun|last3=Minobe|first3=Sumiko|last4=Hamaguchi-Hamada|first4=Kayoko|last5=Kurumata-Shigeto|first5=Mami|last6=Nakamura|first6=Masaru|last7=Namikawa|first7=Hiroshi|title=The nerve ring in cnidarians: its presence and structure in hydrozoan medusae|journal=Zoology|volume=118|issue=2|pages=79–88|doi=10.1016/j.zool.2014.10.001|pmid=25498132|year=2015}}</ref>
''Turritopsis dohrnii'' also has a bottom-living polyp form, or hydroid, which consists of [[stolon]]s that run along the substrate, and upright branches with feeding polyps that can produce medusa buds.<ref>{{cite book|last=Fraser|first=C. McLean|title=Hydroids of the Pacific Coast of Canada and the United States|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=1937|pages=201 plus 44 plates}}</ref> These polyps develop over a few days into tiny 1 mm medusae, which are liberated and swim free from the parent hydroid colony.
Images of both the medusa and polyp of the closely related species ''[[Turritopsis rubra]]'' from [[New Zealand]] can be found online.<ref name="schuchert-10">{{cite web|url=http://www.ville-ge.ch/mhng/hydrozoa/antho/turritopsis-rubra.htm |title=Turritopsis rubra |last=Schuchert |first=Peter |accessdate=23 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912180002/http://www.ville-ge.ch/mhng/hydrozoa/antho/turritopsis-rubra.htm |archivedate=September 12, 2009 }}</ref> Until a recent genetic study, it was thought that ''Turritopsis rubra'' and ''Turritopsis nutricula'' were the same.<ref name=mig/> It is not known whether or not ''T. rubra'' medusae can also transform back into polyps.
== Distribution and invasion ==
''Turritopsis'' is believed to have originated in the [[Pacific]] but has spread all over the world through trans-Arctic migrations, and has speciated into several populations that are easy to distinguish morphologically, but whose species distinctions have recently been verified by a study and comparison of mitochondrial ribosomal gene sequences.<ref name=mig>{{cite journal|last=Miglietta|first=M. P.|author2=S. Piraino |author3=S. Kubota |author4=P. Schuchert|date=November 2006|title=Species in the genus ''Turritopsis'' (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa): a molecular evaluation|journal=Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research|volume=45|issue=1|pages=11–19|publication-date=February 2007|doi=10.1111/j.1439-0469.2006.00379.x}}</ref><ref name="telegraph-09">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/wildlife/4357829/Immortal-jellyfish-swarming-across-the-world.html|title='Immortal' jellyfish swarming across the world |date=January 27, 2009|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=2010-06-16}}</ref> ''Turritopsis'' are found in temperate to tropical regions in all of the world's oceans.<ref name="TimesOnline26012009">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/science/article5594539.ece|title=Turritopsis nutricula: the world's only 'immortal' creature|last=Mintowt-Czyz |first=Lech|date=26 January 2009|publisher=[[Times Online]]|accessdate=2009-03-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203063422/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/science/article5594539.ece|archive-date=February 3, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> ''Turritopsis'' is believed to be spreading across the world through [[Ballast water discharge and the environment|ballast water discharge]].<ref name="TimesOnline26012009" /> Unlike other species invasions which caused serious economic and ecological consequences, T. dohrnii’s invasion around the world was unnoticed due to their tiny size and innocuity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Govindarajan|first=Annette F.|last2=Carman|first2=Mary R.|date=2016-02-01|title=Possible cryptic invasion of the Western Pacific toxic population of the hydromedusa Gonionemus vertens (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa) in the Northwestern Atlantic Ocean|journal=Biological Invasions|language=en|volume=18|issue=2|pages=463–469|doi=10.1007/s10530-015-1019-8|issn=1387-3547}}</ref> "We are looking at a worldwide silent invasion", said [[Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute|Smithsonian Tropical Marine Institute]] scientist Dr. Maria Miglietta.<ref name="telegraph-09"/>
== Life cycle ==
The eggs develop in gonads of female medusae, which are located in the walls of the manubrium (stomach). Mature eggs are presumably spawned and fertilized in the sea by sperm produced and released by male medusae, as is the case for most hydromedusae, although the related species ''Turritopsis rubra'' seems to retain fertilized eggs until the planula stage.<ref name="schuchert-10"/> Fertilized eggs develop into [[planula]] larvae, which settle onto the sea-floor (or even the rich marine communities that live on floating docks), and develop into polyp colonies ([[hydroids]]). The hydroids bud new jellyfishes, which are released at about one millimetre in size and then grow and feed in the plankton, becoming sexually mature after a few weeks (the exact duration depends on the ocean temperature; at {{convert|20|C|F}} it is 25 to 30 days and at {{convert|22|C|F}} it is 18 to 22 days).<ref name="piraino-96"/> Medusae of ''T. dohrnii'' are able to survive between 14 °C and 25 °C.<ref name="piraino-96" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Biological immortality ===
Most jellyfish species have a relatively fixed life-span, which varies by species from hours to many months (long-lived mature jellyfish spawn every day or night; the time is also fairly fixed and species-specific).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mills|first=C. E.|year=1983|title=Vertical migration and diel activity patterns of hydromedusae: studies in a large tank|journal=Journal of Plankton Research|volume=5|pages=619–635|doi=10.1093/plankt/5.5.619|issue=5}}</ref> The medusa of ''Turritopsis dohrnii'' is the only form known to have developed the ability to return to a polyp state, by a specific transformation process that requires the presence of certain cell types (tissue from both the jellyfish bell surface and the circulatory canal system).<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.zmescience.com/science/biology/meet-the-worlds-only-immortal-animal/|title = Meet the world's only immortal animal|date = December 5, 2008|accessdate = January 10, 2015|website = ZME Science|publisher = |last = Mihai|first = Andrei}}</ref>
Careful laboratory experiments have revealed that all stages of the medusae, from newly released to fully mature individuals, can transform back into polyps under the conditions of starvation, sudden temperature change, reduction of salinity and artificial damage of the bell with forceps or scissor.<ref name="piraino-96" /> The transforming [[medusae|medusa]] is characterized first by deterioration of the bell, mesoglea and tentacles. All immature medusa (with 12 tentacles at most) then turned into a [[Microbial cyst|cyst]]-like stage and then transformed into [[stolon]]s and polyps. However, about 20%-40% of mature medusa went into stolons and polyps stage without passing cyst-like stage. Polyps were formed after 2 days since stolons had developed and fed on food. Polyps further multiply by growing additional stolons, branches and then polyps, to form colonial [[hydroids]]. In the experiment, they would eventually transform into stolons and polyps and begin their lives once again even without suffering from environment changes or injury.<ref name="piraino-96" /> Diagram of the transformation procedure can be found at the further reading.
This ability to reverse the biotic cycle (in response to adverse conditions) is unique in the [[animals|animal kingdom]], and allows the jellyfish to bypass death, rendering ''Turritopsis dohrnii'' potentially [[biological immortality|biologically immortal]]. The process has not been observed in their natural habitat, in part because the process is quite rapid, and because field observations at the right moment are unlikely.<ref name="piraino-96" /> Regardless, most individual medusae are likely to fall victim to the general hazards of life as [[plankton]], including being eaten by predators or succumbing to disease.
The species' cell development method of transdifferentiation has inspired scientists to find a way to make stem cells using this process for renewing damaged or dead tissue in [[human]]s.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|last=Dimberu|first=Peniel M.|title=Immortal Jellyfish Provides Clues for Regenerative Medicine|url=http://singularityhub.com/2011/04/25/immortal-jellyfish-provides-clues-for-regenerative-medicine/|publisher=Singularity Hub|accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref>
== Genomic analysis == Genomic analyses such as [[sequence analysis]] on [[Messenger RNA|mRNA]] or [[Mitochondrion|mitochondria]] DNA have been employed to investigate its lifecycle. mRNA analysis of each life stage showed that a stage-specific gene in the medusae stage is expressed tenfold more than in other stages. This gene is relative to a [[Wnt signaling pathway|Wnt signal]] that can induce a regeneration process upon injury.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Logan|first=Catriona Y.|last2=Nusse|first2=Roel|date=2004-10-08|title=The wnt signaling pathway in development and disease|journal=Annual Review of Cell and Developmental Biology|volume=20|issue=1|pages=781–810|doi=10.1146/annurev.cellbio.20.010403.113126|pmid=15473860|issn=1081-0706|citeseerx=10.1.1.322.311}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasegawa|first=Yoshinori|last2=Watanabe|first2=Takashi|last3=Takazawa|first3=Masaki|last4=Ohara|first4=Osamu|last5=Kubota|first5=Shin|date=2016-08-01|title=De Novo Assembly of the Transcriptome of Turritopsis, a Jellyfish that Repeatedly Rejuvenates|journal=Zoological Science|volume=33|issue=4|pages=366–371|doi=10.2108/zs150186|pmid=27498796|issn=0289-0003}}</ref>
Analysis of [[Nucleic acid sequence|nucleotide sequence]] homologs and protein homologs identified ''[[Nemopsis bachei]]'' as the species' closest relative. None of the closely related species show biological immortality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Devarapalli|first=Pratap|last2=Science|first2=Department of Genomic|last3=Kerala|first3=Central University of|last4=Campus|first4=Riverside Transit|last5=Science|first5=Opp: Nehru College of Arts and|last6=17|first6=NH|last7=Padanakkad|last8=Nileshwer|last9=Kasaragod|title=The conserved mitochondrial gene distribution in relatives of Turritopsis nutricula, an immortal jellyfish|url=http://www.bioinformation.net/010/97320630010586.htm|journal=Bioinformation|volume=10|issue=9|pages=586–591|doi=10.6026/97320630010586|pmid=25352727|pmc=4209368|year=2014}}</ref>
==Culturing==
Keeping ''T. dohrnii'' in captivity is quite difficult. Currently only one scientist, Shin Kubota from [[Kyoto University]], has managed to sustain a group of these jellyfish for a prolonged period of time. The plankton must be inspected daily to ensure that they have properly digested the [[Brine shrimp|Artemia cysts]] they are being fed.<ref name=nytm/> Kubota reported that during a two-year period, his colony rebirthed itself 11 times.<ref>{{cite journal|author=S Kubota|title=Repeating rejuvenation in Turritopsis, an immortal hydrozoan (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa)|journal=Biogeography|issn=1345-0662|year=2011|volume=13|number=|pages=101–103|pmid=|url=http://www.benikurage.com/jp/2011biogeography.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029093746/http://www.benikurage.com/jp/2011biogeography.pdf|archivedate=2014-10-29|df=}}</ref> Kubota regularly appears on Japanese television to talk about his immortal jellyfish and has recorded several songs about them.<ref name=nytm>{{cite news |last=Rich|first=Nathaniel|title=Can a jellyfish unlock the secret of immortality? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/02/magazine/can-a-jellyfish-unlock-the-secret-of-immortality.html?src=me&ref=general|work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=November 28, 2012|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}</ref>
==In popular culture== *''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]'' season 2 episode 17 "The Longevity Initiative" – a billionaire tech mogul whose fascination with immortality led him to develop and fund a research team for just that purpose. Leading the research is a scientist who has been injecting the cells of ''T. dohrnii'' into humans in order to hopefully force their cells to regenerate.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Jodi|title=The Longevity Initiative|url=http://www.ew.com/recap/the-blacklist-season-2-episode-17|website=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> *Zoo season 2 episode 6 "Sex, Lies and Jellyfish" – The team searches for immortal jellyfish to find a cure for animal mutations.<ref>{{cite web|last=Walker |first=Jodi |url=http://www.ew.com/recap/zoo-season-2-episode-6 |title=Zoo recap: Sex, Lies and Jellyfish |publisher=EW.com |date=2016-07-27 |accessdate=2016-12-03}}</ref> *[[Wild Kratts]] Videos "Meeting the Immortal Jellyfish" – During the rescue of the Bowhead whale from Zach, Martin and Chris are thrown from the Tortuga, ending up in the Sea of Japan with a group of jellyfish. But these jellyfish are different. They're called the Immortal jellyfish and can live forever. With the help of Aviva, Martin and Chris activate with Immortal jellyfish powers and soon discover the highs and lows of living forever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pbskids.org/video/wild-kratts/2365731408 |title=Meeting the Immortal Jellyfish. Wild Kratts Videos. PBS KIDS |date=2016-04-28 |accessdate=2017-06-24}}</ref> *The design and abilities of the [[Vocaloid]] '''LUMi''' (ルミ) draw inspiration from ''T. dohrnii.'' <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aminoapps.com/page/vocaloid/5820260/lumi-interview-1-reveals-lumis-design|title=LUMi Interview 1 Reveals LUMi's Design!|last=Apps|first=Amino|website=Vocaloid {{!}} aminoapps.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ava01.com/interview/lumi01/|title=キャラクターデザイン 深山フギン｜INTERVIEW｜ヴァーチャルアーティストエージェンシーAVA|website=ヴァーチャルアーティストエージェンシーAVA|language=ja|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref> *Progressive post-metal band [[The Ocean Collective|The Ocean]] wrote the song 'Turritopsis Dohrnii,' inspired by the jellyfish.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.revolvermag.com/music/hear-oceans-sprawling-new-jellyfish-inspired-rager|title=Hear the Ocean's Sprawling New Jellyfish-Inspired Rager|date=18 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
